facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 452 of 1959 was filed by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 25, 1959, of the Madras High Court in S.C. No. 2371 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 452 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 25, 1959, of the Madras High Court in S. C. No. 2371 of 1950.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J. on April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 1. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J. -This appeal by special leave raisesfor companysideration a very short but by numbermeans an easy question

facts.text: The testatrix was Mrs. Mary Magdelene Coelho, an Indian Christian lady of the Roman Catholic faith and a widow.

anchor.surface_text: The testatrix was an Indian Christian lady of the- Roman Catholic faith-Mrs. Mary Magdelene Coelho. She was a widow and was possessed of companysiderable properties

facts.text: The testatrix executed the will on July 25, 1907 relating to properties remaining after previous settlements in favour of her children.

anchor.surface_text: She was a widow and was possessed of companysiderable properties in respect of which she had previously executed settlements in favour of her children. The will whose companystruction falls for determination was executed on July 25, 1907

facts.text: By the date of the will, only two daughters were alive: eldest Severina Sabina Brito and second Mary Matilda Coelho.

anchor.surface_text: She had originally four daughters, but by the date of the will only two of them were alive-her eldest Severina Sabina Brito and her second Mary Matilda Coelho.

facts.text: Grand-daughter Juli Mary Margaret Fernandez was alive, by her deceased 4th daughter.

anchor.surface_text: The other members of her family then alive and to whom it is necessary to refer were a grand-daughter- Juli Mary Margaret Fernandez by her deceased 4th daughter

facts.text: Four sons of the eldest daughter Severina were alive.

anchor.surface_text: and four sons of the eldest daughter Severina. It may be added that the third daughter who died before 1907 left numberissue.

facts.text: The third daughter died before 1907 leaving no issue.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that the third daughter who died before 1907 left numberissue. We might number proceed to the terms of the will.

facts.text: The suit for partition and separate possession was filed in September 1946 by the widow and daughter of Denis, one of the sons of Severina.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit for partition and separate possession filed in September, 1946 by the widow and daughter of Denis--one of the sons of Mrs. Severina Sabina

facts.text: The property in suit measures 1 acre 37 cents with houses and structures, part of property covered by cl. 3.

anchor.surface_text: and relates to the property measuring 1 acre 37 cents with houses and structures thereon which is part of the property companyered by cl. 3.

facts.text: Severina died on February 14, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: We ought to mention that Severina died on February 14, 1946. It is the case of the plaintiffs that Severina acquired under the terms of cl. 3  c

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed that Severina acquired only a life interest under cl. 3(c) and remainder vested in her male issues.

anchor.surface_text: It is the case of the plaintiffs that Severina acquired under the terms of cl. 3  c only a life interest in that property and that the remainder in absolute was companyferred upon her male issues.

facts.text: Defendants claimed that Severina took absolute interest under cl. 3(c), so her interest passed in court auction sale in execution of decree against her.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the companystruction put forward by the companytesting defendants who claim under a purchaser in a Court sale in execution of a decree against Severina is, that on a proper interpretation of the clause what was companyferred on Severina was an absolute interest

facts.text: Trial judge upheld defendants' construction and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned Trial judge as well as the District judge on appeal upheld the companystruction companytended for by the defendants and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: District judge on appeal upheld defendants' construction and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned Trial judge as well as the District judge on appeal upheld the companystruction companytended for by the defendants and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Madras High Court single judge reversed the decree, held Severina had life interest, and decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal to the High Court the learned Single judge reversed this decree and decreed the suit holding that the daughter Severina obtained only a life interest in the property companyered by cl. 3.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that under cl. 3(c), Severina took only a life interest, with absolute remainder to her male issues.

anchor.surface_text: This was the interpretation which the learned Single judge of the High Court adopted and we companysider the same is companyrect.

facts.text: The will is in Canarese language.

anchor.surface_text: We ought to mention that the original will is in the Canarese language and there has been some dispute as regards the companyrect translation of this relevant clause.

facts.text: Clause 3(c) of the will bequeaths movable properties and remaining immovables to eldest daughter Severina to enjoy after testatrix's death, and after her lifetime her male children to enjoy permanently with absolute right.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3  c  which effects the disposition number to be companystrued reads 3.  c  All kinds of movable properties that shall be in my possession and authority at the time of my death, i.e., all kinds of movable properties inclusive of the amounts that shall be got from others and the cash-all these my eldest daughter Severina Sobina Coelho, shall after my death, enjoy and after her lifetime, her male children also shall enjoy permanently and with absolute right

facts.text: There were numerous proceedings between parties before the suit and several parties died during pendency, legal representatives added.

anchor.surface_text: Pausing here, we ought to mention that there have been numerous proceedings between the parties before the suit giving rise to the appeal but that it is unnecessary to refer to them and that besides, several of the parties have died during the pendency of the proceedings and their legal representatives have beep added to the record.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated August 25, 1959, of the Madras High Court in S. C. No. 2371 of 1950.
the Indian Succession Act X of 1865 which was in force in 1907 govern the interpretation of this will.

concepts.interpretation: Governs interpretation of will of Indian Christian testatrix executed in 1907; relevant provisions re-enacted in 1925 Act.

anchor.surface_text: s. 82 Where property is bequeathed to any person, he is entitled to the whole interest of the testator therein, unless it appears from the Will that only a restricted interest was intended for him.

concepts.interpretation: Presumption in favour of absolute interest unless contrary intention appears; not displaced here as words after lifetime show restricted interest.

issues.text: whether under cl. 3 c extracted above the interest which the eldest daughter Severina took under the bequest was absolute or whether she had merely a life interest with the absolute remainder vesting in her male issues

anchor.surface_text: The short question for decision in the appeal is whether under cl. 3  c  extracted above the interest which the eldest daughter Severina took under the bequest was absolute or whether she had merely a life interest with the absolute remainder vesting in ,her male issues,

issues.text: the question arising on the construction of cl. 3 c would be whether the words shall enjoy permanently and with absolute right apply to the interest of Severina or are they confined to designate exclusively the interest of her male-children who are to take after her life-time

anchor.surface_text: It would be seen that in ultimate analysis the question arising on the companystruction of cl. 3  c  would be whether the words shall enjoy permanently and with absolute right apply to the interest of Severina or are they companyfined to designate exclusively the interest of her male-children who are to take after her life-time.

issues.text: the question is whether the words that follow which refer to the male children enjoying permanently and with absolute rights... designate them as direct objects of a distinct and independent gift, or are they added merely to denote the nature of the interest which the first taker-Severina was to obtain

anchor.surface_text: Applying the terms of s. 84 to the present case, numberdoubt property is bequeathed to a person viz, the daughter, but the question is whether the words that follow which refer to the male children enjoying permanently and with absolute rights, for there is numberdoubt that on any interpretation of the document those words do apply to them, designate them as direct objects of a distinct arid independent gift, or are they added merely to denote the nature of the interest which the first taker-Severina was to obtain?

issues.text: the sole point for consideration on which the decision in the appeal turns is whether under cl. 3 c Severina, the eldest daughter of the testatrix acquired an absolute interest or was her interest merely limited to one for her life, the absolute remainder being bequeathed to her male issues

anchor.surface_text: As we stated earlier, the sole point for companysideration on which the decision in the appeal turns is whether under cl. 3  c  Severina, the eldest daughter of the testatrix acquired an absolute interest or was her interest merely limited to one for her life, the absolute remainder being bequeathed to her male issues.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3 c which effects the disposition now to be construed reads 3. c All kinds of movable properties... shall after my death, enjoy and after her lifetime, her male children also shall enjoy permanently and with absolute right

holdings.text: Under clause 3(c) of the will, Severina took only a life interest in the property, with the absolute remainder vesting in her male issues.

anchor.surface_text: This was the interpretation which the learned Single judge of the High Court adopted and we consider the same is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause construed using s.84 illustration (c), words after lifetime create successive interests; cardinal principle to give effect to every disposition by cutting down apparent absolute to life estate.

holdings.text: The case falls within illustration (c) to section 84 of the Indian Succession Act, 1865, where a bequest to A for life and after death to issue creates successive interests.

anchor.surface_text: Put in technical language are the words referring to the male children, words of purchase or are they words of limitation indicating the nature of the interest conveyed to the first taker. It would be observed that in illustration a to s. 84 the bequest is made to the first taker and his descendants. ... In our opinion the case on hand would fall within illustration c and the bequest to Severina is only of life interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'after her lifetime, her male children also shall enjoy permanently' create life interest followed by remainder, distinguishing from ill.(a) where words denote quality of first taker's estate.

holdings.text: The words referring to the male children enjoying permanently and with absolute rights designate them as direct objects of a distinct and independent gift (words of purchase), not merely denoting the nature of Severina's interest (words of limitation).

anchor.surface_text: Applying the terms of s. 84 to the present case, no doubt property is bequeathed to a person viz, the daughter, but the question is whether the words that follow which refer to the male children enjoying permanently and with absolute rights... designate them as direct objects of a distinct and independent gift, or are they added merely to denote the nature of the interest which the first taker-Severina was to obtain?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under s.84, words after lifetime indicate independent gift to male children as successive takers, not joint or descriptive of Severina's estate.

holdings.text: The presumption under section 82 of absolute interest is displaced as the will shows a restricted interest was intended for Severina.

anchor.surface_text: s. 84 Where property is bequeathed to a person, and words are added which describe a class of persons, but do not denote them as direct objects of a distinct and independent gift, such person is entitled to the whole interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'after her lifetime' clearly indicate intention for restricted life interest, followed by gift over.

holdings.text: To give effect to every disposition in the will, Severina's apparently absolute interest is cut down to a life interest to accommodate the absolute remainder to her male children.

anchor.surface_text: one of the cardinal principles of construction of wills that to the extent that it is legally possible effect should be given to every disposition contained in the will unless the law prevents effect being given to it. ... where there is a bequest to A even though it be in terms apparently absolute followed by a gift of the same to B absolutely on or after or at As death, A is prima facie held to take a life interest and B an interest in remainder

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cardinal principle favors construction avoiding repugnancy and voiding gift over; prefers successive interests over absolute followed by invalid remainder.

holdings.text: The translation by the High Court judge is nearer the original, with 'enjoy' for Severina and then permanent absolute for male issue after her lifetime; word 'too/also' does not extend absolute right to Severina.

anchor.surface_text: salutary rule that save in exceptional cases if the correctness of an official translation is disputed by any party steps must be taken to have a retranslation made by the officers of the Court ... We consider that the translation which was got prepared by the learned judge in the High Court is nearer the original in spirit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal translation supports distinct interests; contrast in phraseology shows Severina's interest different from successors'.

holdings.text: Phrases like 'after her lifetime' or 'after death' indicate life interest without needing explicit alienation prohibition, as seen in clauses 4 and 5.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of will; cl.5 has life interest without prohibition, using similar words.

holdings.text: In will construction, precedents are of no help as each will must be construed in its own terms and setting.

anchor.surface_text: in the matter of the construction of a will authorities or precedents were of no help as each will has to be construed in its own terms and in the setting in which the clauses occur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General observation on uniqueness of wills.

anchor.surface_text: one of the cardinal principles of construction of wills that to the extent that it is legally possible effect should be given to every disposition contained in the will unless the law prevents effect being given to it. ... where there is a bequest to A even though it be in terms apparently absolute followed by a gift of the same to B absolutely on or after or at As death, A is prima facie held to take a life interest and B an interest in remainder
This was the interpretation which the learned Single judge of the High Court adopted and we consider the same is correct. Quite a number of authorities were cited by learned
